page.title: 07Dew Pond Study.
page.content: If you look at a map of our block the first thing that you notice is that there are a large number of dew ponds. While many of these naturally result from the clay soil a number of them are old clay tile quarries. Most are surrounded by trees and have some have steep banks which are covered with bluebells in early summer. The pond that we surveyed included among the surrounding trees oaks, willows,rowan and hawthorn and vegetat -ion on the water consisted of water- lilies,bullrushes and pond weed. We caught broad-bodied dragonfly larvae, two sticklebacks and six waterboatmen. We saw a pregnant female stickleback. Then we caught a helobdella leech. on the surface were moorhens and mallard duck which feed on insects in and around the pond.
